repnme.cdata!:
Niger - First and Second Rural and Social
            Policy Credit/Grant (RSRC-1 and RSRC-2) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First and Second Rural
            and Social Policy Credit/Grant (RSRC-1 and RSRC-2) Project
            for Niger were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: design of the budget supports needs to be
            adapted to the institutional environment. In a weak
            institutional environment such as Niger, it is better to
            avoid a long list of prior actions, and focus instead on a
            short list of key actions and their cross-sectoral linkages
            and synergies. It is important to provide a medium-term
            perspective, particularly when addressing policy constraints
            in sectors, where results are not achieved in the
            short-term. In that respect, the decision to discontinue the
            series of three rural and social policy reform operations
            and move to other sectors before gains in the initial
            sectors are fully consolidated is perplexing. This decision
            may give the Government the wrong signal that pursuing the
            reforms in the human development area is no longer needed.
            The Development Policy Lending (DPL) series demonstrated
            that satisfactory outcomes can be achieved with strong
            commitment on the part of government and with Bank support
            designed to develop the needed capacity for implementation.
            This is particularly evident in the education, health, and
            to a lesser extent in agriculture sectors, where authorities
            are committed to improve capacities and increase efficiency
            of service delivery.

            Policy Credit/Grant (RSRC-1 and RSRC-2) Project

repnme.cdata!:
Niger - Rural and Social Sector Policy
            Reform Project : partial waiver of one prior action for the
            release of the second tranche

abstracts.cdata!:
This memorandum recommends the release
            of the second tranche of the Rural and Social Policy Reform
            Credit (RSRC-1) (Credit No. 4189) for Niger. The memorandum
            argues that the Government of Niger has made satisfactory
            progress overall in implementing the program supported by
            the credit as set forth in its Letter of Development Policy
            and has fully met eight of the nine prior actions for
            release of the second tranche. A partial waiver for one
            prior condition related to the regional recruitment process
            for qualified health staff is being requested which was
            prior action number 8: Pass the ministerial arrete
            (published in the Official Gazette) for the launching of a
            regional recruitment process for qualified staff (national
            total of 715 contractual agents and civil servants) to
            address the human resource deficit in the public health
            sector in accordance with the recipient's strategic
            objectives. Given the shortage of qualified available health
            staff; this gap could not be filled, but the provision is
            waived based on Niger's efforts in still trying to meet
            this objective and Niger's satisfactory progress overall.

repnme.cdata!:
Niger - Rural and Social Policy Reform
            Credit Development Policy Lending (DPL) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural and Social Policy Reform
            Credit Development Policy Lending (DPL) Project, as part of
            a series of two to three operations, aims to help the
            Government of Niger improve service delivery to the poor,
            while continuing reforms in public sector management to
            secure adequate financing in critical sectors of the
            economy. Within this medium-term framework, and building on
            the previous three budget support operations, as well as
            ongoing investment projects in agriculture, education, and
            health, the project will focus on selected policy and
            institutional aspects towards a) improving public sector
            management, through expansion of reforms in public
            expenditure management - increasing links between budget
            allocations and Government priorities, strengthening
            sectoral ministries' involvement in budget regulation
            and cash management, modernizing the Treasury, and,
            strengthening budget controls; and b) enhancing the national
            statistical information system, ensuring the preparation of
            national surveys on a regular basis. The project will also
            promote rural development and agricultural growth through
            programs implementation within the rural development
            strategy, promote local governance of natural resources
            (agricultural land, irrigation water), adopt a single
            medium-term expenditure framework (MTEF), and, release the
            funds allocated in the 2006 budget to ensure adequate food
            availability during the pre-harvest period. Furthermore,
            improvements in service delivery in social sectors will be
            enhanced through an adequate human resource management.
            Budget preparation and execution will be improved, as will
            accountability and governance at the school level, and the
            provision of publicly financed basic health services to the
            poor and vulnerable groups.
